perdidas-solvente-sx.subtitle: Solvent extraction (SX) is the heart of copper hydrometallurgy. But every liter of organic lost is money escaping from your operation.
perdidas-solvente-sx.author: TSF Technical Team

content.title: The Context: SX-EW Dominates the Industry
content.text:
In 2025, over 60% of new mining projects opt for hydrometallurgical methods like SX-EW instead of traditional smelting. The reasons are clear: lower capital investment, greater operational flexibility, and better environmental profile.

But this technology has an Achilles' heel: organic solvent losses.

content.title: The Real Problem
content.text: In a typical SX plant, organic losses come from:
list: Aqueous entrainment - Organic droplets that escape with the raffinate
Chemical degradation - Extractant degrades from oxidation and contaminants
Stable emulsions - Fine solids and crud that trap irrecoverable organic
Leaks and spills - Mechanical losses in the circuit

content.text: With extractant prices exceeding $8-12 USD/liter, a plant losing 100-200 liters daily is losing $300,000 - $900,000 USD annually just in reagent replacement.

content.title: But the real cost is higher
content.text: Degraded organic means lower extraction efficiency, higher energy consumption in EW, and lower purity cathodes.

content.title: Technological Advances 2025-2026
content.text: The industry is responding with innovations:
list: AI Optimization: Real-time sensors adjust parameters to maximize recovery
Modular electrowinning cells: Higher efficiency, lower energy consumption
Centrifuge technology: More effective separation of organic and aqueous phases

content.title: The Solution: Organic Treatment and Recovery
content.text: Specialized treatment of degraded organic enables:

items.label: Solvent Recovery
items.description: Organic that appears lost in emulsions and crud can be recovered through specialized separation processes.

items.label: Loss Reduction
items.description: By eliminating contaminants that cause degradation, treated organic lasts longer in the circuit.

items.label: Months Between Treatments
items.description: Plants that treated every 12-15 months now extend the cycle significantly.

content.title: Operation Stabilization
content.text: Stable emulsions are the enemy of SX efficiency. They cause longer phase separation times, excessive entrainment to EW, and cathode contamination. Treatment eliminates emulsion precursors, returning stability to the circuit.

content.title: Real Case: Measurable Impact
content.description: A copper SX plant processing 50,000 annual tons implemented organic treatment:

content.text: Annual savings exceeded $3.1 million USD considering lower reagent replacement, higher metal recovery, and elimination of cathode quality penalties.

content.title: When to Consider Organic Treatment
content.text: Your SX plant probably needs treatment if you observe:
list: Phase separation times exceeding 3-4 minutes
Recurring crud formation in settlers
Organic entrainment to electrolyte >15 ppm
Visible organic color degradation (darkening)
Extractant consumption above industry benchmark
Extraction efficiency drop without apparent cause

content.title: Mobile Treatment Advantages
content.text: Mobile treatment solutions offer unique benefits:
list: No capital investment: Monthly service instead of buying equipment
No plant modifications: Treatment is performed parallel to the circuit
No additional permits: Temporary installation requires no environmental approvals
Flexibility: Scale as needed, from pilots to continuous treatment

content.text:
Solvent losses in SX are not an inevitable cost of operation. With the right technology and approach, it's possible to recover up to 98% of degraded organic and reduce ongoing losses by over 60%.

In a context where Chile and Peru project significant copper production increases toward 2030, optimizing every aspect of SX-EW operation is not optional - it's a competitive advantage.

litio-triangulo-agua.subtitle: Argentina could become the world's largest lithium producer in the next decade. But to achieve this, the industry must solve a critical problem: water.
litio-triangulo-agua.author: TSF Technical Team

content.title: The Latin American Lithium Boom
content.text:
The "Lithium Triangle" - Argentina, Chile, and Bolivia - holds 68% of the world's reserves of this critical mineral for energy transition. And demand keeps growing.

In 2025 alone, global lithium demand will increase 24% year-over-year, driven mainly by electric vehicles representing 65% of consumption. Projections indicate 15% annual growth - no other mineral has a comparable trajectory.
Argentina is positioning aggressively. In June 2024, the government announced a 10-year plan with 4 new mining projects that will increase annual capacity by 79% (202,000 additional metric tons).

content.title: The Problem: 21 Million Liters Daily
content.text:
Lithium extraction from brines consumes water. A lot of water.

The wetlands of Argentina, Bolivia, and Chile face a significant threat: lithium mining consumes approximately 21 million liters of water daily in the region. This massive consumption is contributing to:
list: Persistent droughts in already arid zones
Agricultural decline in local communities
Notable reduction in wildlife populations
Conflicts with indigenous communities

content.text: In 2024, a court in Argentina's Catamarca province suspended new mining permits over water-related concerns. This legal precedent is changing the rules of the game.

content.title: Regulatory Pressure Grows
content.text: Companies are responding in different ways:

content.title: Chile: "Green Lithium"
content.text: Chile is betting on "green lithium," arguing that sustainability and traceability can command a premium price from automakers. The strategy seeks to protect local communities from commodity boom-and-bust cycles.

content.title: Argentina: DLE as Promise
content.text: Companies promote Direct Lithium Extraction (DLE), a technology presented as less resource-intensive. However, this technology has not yet been proven at industrial scale.

content.title: The Reality
content.text: With lithium prices that have fallen significantly from their 2022 peak, some operations are reducing production or delaying expansions. Mining towns that prospered during the boom now face difficulties.

content.title: Where Filtration Comes In
content.text: Regardless of the extraction technology used, all lithium operations require:
list: Brine clarification - Remove suspended solids before processing
Effluent treatment - Meet standards before discharge or recirculation
Water recovery - Maximize reuse to reduce net consumption
Sludge handling - Dewater residues for responsible disposal

content.title: Mobile Filtration Advantages for Lithium
content.text: Lithium projects in the Triangle face unique challenges that make mobile solutions especially attractive:

items.label: Locations
items.description: Salt flats are in hard-to-access, high-altitude areas. Mobile systems arrive ready to operate.

items.label: Market
items.description: With fluctuating prices, the service model allows scaling according to market conditions.

items.label: Permits
items.description: Mobile systems, being temporary, avoid the regulatory bottleneck.

items.label: Adaptation
items.description: Each salt flat has different chemical composition. Mobile equipment reconfigures easily.

content.title: The Geopolitical Factor
content.text:
China currently dominates the lithium value chain - from extraction to refining and processing. It is the largest investor in lithium projects in Latin America.

But with current trade tensions (U.S. tariffs, Chinese export restrictions), Western battery manufacturers seek to diversify suppliers. Latin America is at the center of this geopolitical competition.

content.title: Recommendations for Lithium Operators
list: Audit your water consumption - Identify where it's lost and where it can be recirculated
Evaluate clarification technologies - Not all discarded water is really unusable
Consider mobile solutions for pilots - Before investing in permanent infrastructure, validate with flexible equipment
Document your environmental management - Premium buyers will pay more for "green" lithium with demonstrable traceability
Prepare for regulatory scrutiny - What happened in Catamarca can replicate in other jurisdictions

content.text:
Latin American lithium has a bright future, but only if the industry solves the water dilemma. Operations that manage to maximize production while minimizing water impact will be the ones that thrive in the next decade.

Filtration and clarification are not glamorous, but they are fundamental. Every cubic meter of water recirculated instead of discarded is one less cubic meter of community conflict, one less cubic meter of regulatory risk, and one more step toward the "green lithium" the market demands.

content.title: The New Regulatory Framework
content.text: Chile has established the world's strictest rules for water use in mining. The National Mining Policy 2050 is not a suggestion - it's a binding roadmap that will transform how every mine in the country operates.

content.title: What It Means For Operations
content.text: Major miners are already responding. BHP and Antofagasta currently use 30% desalinated water, with a target to reach 50% by 2030. But for medium and small operations, the challenge is greater.
The copper sector's water consumption will grow 2.3% annually to reach 23.7 m³/s by 2034. Seawater use will increase 230% this decade.

content.title: Compliance Technologies
content.text: Operations have several options to comply:
list: Desalination - Expensive but independent of continental sources
Advanced recirculation - Treatment and reuse of process water
Effluent clarification - Water recovery from waste streams
Tailings thickening - Reduction of water sent to dams

content.title: The Role of Filtration
content.text: Mobile filtration allows operations to implement recirculation without large capital investments. A clarification system can recover 80-90% of water from streams currently discarded, directly contributing to recirculation target compliance.

Mining Policy 2050 is non-negotiable. Operations that don't adapt will face operational restrictions, fines, and eventually, closure. Investment in water management technologies is not an expense - it's the license to keep operating.

content.title: The Maintenance Challenge
content.text: More production means more equipment wear. Scheduled and unscheduled maintenance shutdowns will be more frequent and more critical. During these periods, filtration capacity becomes the bottleneck.
list: SX plants require organic treatment during shutdowns
EW cells need cleaning and crud removal
Clarification systems must remain operational
Crud filtration cannot stop

content.text: Mobile filtration allows maintaining operations during fixed equipment shutdowns. A backup system can be deployed in 24-48 hours, avoiding production losses that can exceed $100,000 USD per day of unplanned downtime.

The copper boom is a historic opportunity for Latin America. But seizing it requires reliable and resilient operations. Companies that invest in backup capacity and flexible solutions will be the ones capturing the full value of this bull cycle.
